data.text:
Kampala City

Kampala is the capital city of Uganda and is a stand-alone tourist attraction in Uganda whereby one can opt for a City Tour than the National Parks in Uganda. Kampala is the most developed city in Uganda and it is divided into five divisions including Kawempe Division, Makindye Division, Rubaga Division, Nakawa Division, Wakiso District, in the recent years the population increased to over 2 million.

Kampala is the 14th fastest growing city in the world, and the population growth rate is 5 percent. It is ranked the best city in East Africa. The city is ahead of Kigali and Nairobi and this research was carried out by the New York Times.

Kampala the capital city of Uganda was originally called the old Kampala hill. The summit is located on the former Fort Lugard and was the headquarters of the British Colonialists which is Uganda’s Protectorate.

The word Kampala runs from a local word Impala. This was after the British arrival in Uganda when they spotted a number of Impalas on the hill. Hill of Impala as Akasozi Ke’mpala whereby Akasozi means ‘Hill”, “ke’mpala” meaning “of impalas”.

Kampala capital city of Uganda is under the Authority of the Kampala Capital City Authority, and this gives the government more control of the administration of Kampala city. This act created the Kampala Metropolitan physical planning Authority, and this was with the aim of improving the infrastructure of Kampala and the areas of Mukono town, Wakiso district, Luwero district, and Mpigi.

This Capital City has two seasons in the city i.e. the wet and dry seasons. The city experiences wet season from the months of August to December and February to June. However, between February and June, Kampala receives heavier rainfalls. While the rest of the months its usually dry season.

Attractions in Kampala City

The City was built on seven hills and all of them have tourist attractions including

Kasubi Tombs: it’s a burial ground for the royal family of the Buganda kingdom.

Old Kampala hill: This is where Fort Lugard was located this was the first seat of the British Colonialists in the country.

Mengo Hill, this was the capital city of the Buganda Kingdom during the colonial rule however still today some regard it as a city of the King.

Kibuli Hill, this where the Kibuli Mosque is located.

Namirembe hill is a home to the Anglican church of the Buganda religious wars of 1889 to 1893 which is a site of Namirembe Anglican Cathedral.

Lubaga Hill is a home to the white father’s catholic of the Buganda religious wars a site of the Rubaga catholic cathedral.

Nsambya Hill,is a site of the former cathedral of st Peters Nsambya which is a British catholic Mill Hill Mission it was built during the Uganda Agreement 190o. Nakasero Hill is a summit for Fort Nakasero, a British Military after relocating from Fort Lugard in old Kampala, Nakasero hill was a former site for the European Hospital the hospital is opposite the Ministry of Public Service Headquarters.

There are many Tribes in Kampala including the Banyonkole, Buganda, Swahili, Luganda, English, Alur, Bagisu, Bakiga, Bafumbira, Basoga, Banyoro, Langi, Acholi, Langi and Bamasaba.

There is cultural experiences in Kampala including Ndere Culture Centre which is located in Kisasi. The centre has promoted Uganda’s and African culture through music, dance and drama.

The main transport in Kampala is Road transport, and this is used by tourists and the local people. There are cars as well as Boda-Bodas (motorbikes) that are used mostly during the rushing hours of traffic.
